intro: Allium nazarenum subsp. nazarenum, commonly known as the Nazarene leek, is a perennial bulbous plant native to the Mediterranean region. It typically grows to a height of about 30–60 centimeters, featuring slender, grass-like leaves and clusters of small, white or pale purple flowers. The plant produces small, ovoid bulbs that are edible and resemble those of the common leek. It thrives in well-drained soil and full sun, making it a suitable candidate for rock gardens or borders. Its botanical characteristics make it a distinctive and ornamental addition to gardens.
